Scheme

This page is under construction!

Lists

  1. Write a function attach which returns a new list with elem added to the end of a list. Do not use the built-in function append. scm> (attach 1000 '()) (1000) scm> (attach 4 '(1 2 3)) (1 2 3 4) scm> (attach 2 (list 4 3 5)) (4 3 5 2)

    (define (attach elem lst)
  "YOUR CODE HERE"
)
 (if (null? lst) (list elem)
  (cons (car lst) (attach elem (cdr lst))))
)

    toggle solution

    What will the following call return? 

    scm> (attach '(d e) '(a b c))
    (a b c (d e))
    TOGGLE SOLUTION

  2. Implement append, which takes two lists and combines them into one.

    scm> (append '() '(1 2 3))
(1 2 3)
scm> (append '(a b c) '())
(a b c)
scm> (append '(c s) '(6 1 a))
(c s 6 1 a)
    (define (append lst1 lst2)
  "YOUR CODE HERE"
)
  (if (null? lst1) lst2
   (cons (car lst1) (append (cdr lst1) lst2)))
)

    TOGGLE SOLUTION

Tail Recursion

  1. Look at the solutions I've provided for attach and append. What are the tail calls? Are the functions tail recursive?

    attach is not tail recursive. The tail calls are a call to list and a call to cons. The tail call for append is to cons. This is also not tail recursive, since the recursive call is passed as an argument to cons.
    TOGGLE SOLUTION

  2. Implement len-tail, which is a tail recursive procedure that returns the length of the input list.

    Hint: Use a helper function to keep track of and increment the length.
    scm> (len-tail '())
0
scm> (len-tail '(1 2 3))
3
    (define (len-tail lst)
  "YOUR CODE HERE"
)
  (define (helper lst result) 
    (if (null? lst) result
    (helper (cdr lst) (+ 1 result))))
 (helper lst 0)
)
    TOGGLE SOLUTION   TOGGLE HINT

  3. Without using len-tail, implement compare-len, which takes in two lists and outputs 0 if they're the same length, 1 if lst1 is longer, or 2 if lst2 is longer. 

    scm> (compare-len (list 1 2 3) (list 4 5 6)
0
scm>  (compare-len '(3 3 3 3) '(5 5 5))
1
scm>  (compare-len '(h i) '(b y e))
2
    (define (compare-len lst1 lst2)
  "YOUR CODE HERE"
)
  (cond ((and (null? lst1) (null? lst2)) 0)
       ((null? lst1) 1)
       ((null? lst2) 2)
       (else (compare-len (cdr lst1) (cdr lst2))))
)
    TOGGLE SOLUTION

Streams

  1. Write a function powers that returns a stream of all the powers of n. 
    scm> (powers 3)
(3 . #[promise (not forced)])
scm> (stream-to-list (powers 3) 10)
(3 9 27 81 243 729 2187 6561 19683 59049)
scm> (stream-to-list (powers 2) 10)
(2 4 8 16 32 64 128 256 512 1024)
    (define (powers n)
  "YOUR CODE HERE"
)
  (define (helper curr)
    (cons-stream curr (helper (* n curr))))
    (helper n)
)
    TOGGLE SOLUTION
